LJava
Class Variable

java.lang.Object
  LJava.Variable

public class Variable
extends java.lang.Object

A class defining a Variable in the logical engine of LJava. This structure is mutable until it is set to be a certain value, which then it becomes immutable. All Variables should be defined using the 'var' method like in the following code: Variable x=var(); A care should be taken if placing a Variable as an attribute in a wrapper. This might lead to a StackOverFlowException (Read more in the 'LJ' class definition under the 'exists' method definition).

Author:
Tzali Maimon

Field Detail

none

public static final Relation none
Serves as a no-value relation as a value for variables that was instantiated to have no value. The value of this static field equals only to itself.

Method Detail

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object x)
This will compare the value that this Variable holds against another object. NOTE: Variable.equals(Object) is not the same as Object.equals(Variable). The first compares the principle value which Variable holds (if any) and checks if it is equal to the given object. The second one compare Object and Variable as OBJECTS!

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
x - Object to compare to.
Returns:
True if equals.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

get

public java.lang.Object get()
Returns a Variable current value. If it has only a single value it will return it as an object. If there is no current value is available the method will return the special relation none. For constrains it always return the first correct value in the set of values (as it is was sorted in the moment of instantiation).

Returns:
An object which is the value of the Variable.

getConstrain

public java.lang.Object[] getConstrain()
Returns an array of objects of the values in the constrain over this variable. If the Variable hasn't instantiated yet the array will contain one value which will be the Variable itself. If the Variable has no possible values the array will contain one value which will be the special relation 'none'.

Returns:
An array of objects.

getFlatConstrain

public java.util.HashSet<java.lang.Object> getFlatConstrain()
Returns an unsynchronized hash set of the values in the variable. Beware that this method doesn't change the variable but still might change it's returned set even though the variable is immutable. Unlike getConstrain() which return the actual array which holds the values for the constrain of this variable, this method turns this array to a set. Example: let x be a variable with constrain = [1,2,3,y] where y is a variable which hasn't been instantiated yet. then getConstrain and getFlatConstrain will return array and set which holds the same values which are: 1,2,3,y. Now let y be instantiated into the value of 2. Then getConstrain is still stable and it's value is still 1,2,3,y which will be typed out: 1,2,3,[2]. In the contrary, getFlatConstrain will return a set containing 1,2,3 which is not longer equal to the values in the array. Note that if you want to compare a variable value to another object you should do that through get() which return the principle main value of this variable if it exists. That is to say that even when a variable holds a constrain within it, it actually equals only a single value once it is instantiated.

Returns:
A hash set of the values of the constrain of this Variable.

equalConstrain

public boolean equalConstrain(Variable x)
Compare this variable constrain set of values to the given variable constrain set of values. Return True if all the values of one are the possible values of the other. This should not be used when a variable has only one possible value since this method is obviously much slower than equals. The method sorts both of the variables values arrays and then compare the arrays. This uses Arrays.sort so you will get an O(nlgn) running time from the method.

Parameters:
x - A variable to compare to
Returns:
A boolean expression

set

public boolean set(java.lang.Object... args)
Instantiates the variable with all values in args. A consistency check is performed on each element that is set as a value to prevent logical chain (x that point to y that points to x). This is performed by temporary announcing that this variable is being instantiated and such variables are considered inconsistent absolutely to any other variable. Once all the values are checked for consistency the variable is considered consistent again. In case of a logical loop between a chain of Variables, they will all be instantiated to the relation nil. After a Variable finishes to set, he cannot be set again and the method will just return false;

Parameters:
args - Values
Returns:
True if succeeded.
